metadata.titleEn: Whole-genome microarray data of 150 Tibetan populations on the Tibetan Plateau (2022)
metadata.description: The qinghai-tibet plateau is one of the most challenging environment for human survival, is known as the "third pole" of the earth.At an average altitude of 4000 meters, 4000 m (only for sea level by about 60%.Plateau of oxygen for human survival is a strong selection pressure, most of the plateau non-adaptive individuals exposed to plateau hypoxia environment will cause the red blood cells (red blood cells increased disease) increase in the number and the backlog of red blood cells, Hematocrit (HCT) levels.Plateau Tibetan genetic background of the single, high altitude environment for a long time to adapt to the related genes on the plateau has the effect that is choosing, result in different altitude gradient in the relevant single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPS) chain stable genetic differences, suitable for the research of high altitude adaptation between phenotype and genotype.This research adopts the methods of DNA microarray (DNA Array), compared with 150 cases of the Tibetan plateau and the Tibetan male genome-wide microarray data in east asians, each sample to obtain about 700000 loci (including nuclear genome, mitochondrial DNA and Y chromosome) classification results, analysis of the differences between SNPs, genes and signaling pathways, and detection of plateau Tibetan men in order to adapt to high altitude hypoxia environment characteristics of adaptive evolution at the molecular level.This data can help in Tibetan population genetic adaptation from the nuclear genome aspects, through the comparison of data with the plateau surrounding population, can be more comprehensive understanding of the plateau native men of adaptive evolution.For the study of human and biological evolution, to explore the molecular of high and low altitude population level difference, the different geographical environment of human kinship and low oxygen to supply a basis for the choice of the function of genes of genetic reference data.

background: With an extreme and harsh environment that is generally considered inhospitable to humans, the Tibetan Plateau (TP) has been inhabited since the late upper Pleistocene. In contrast to the earliest occupation by hunter-gatherers during the Late Paleolithic era, whose contribution to the current Tibetan gene pool was rather limited, migration onto the plateau appears to have occurred during the Neolithic period. Archaeological evidence further suggests that permanent human occupation began ∼3.6 kilo-years ago (ka), and was most likely facilitated by the introduction and utilization of cold-tolerant barley agriculture and sheep, which were first domesticated in west Asia around 10 ka. As revealed by archaeological evidence, modern humans settled extensively in the northeastern TP (below 2500 m above sea level (masl)) with millet cultivation around ∼5.2 ka, and further expanded to high-altitude plateau areas (above 2500 masl) ∼3.6 ka with barley and sheep from west Asia. According to previous genetic studies, most Tibetan genetic components can be traced back to Neolithic immigrations from northern China, raising the possibility that it was millet farmers who brought barley agriculture to the TP around 3.6 ka. Given the limited molecular resolution, and a lack of both genetic and archaeological evidence in previous studies, it remains unclear whether these lineages are associated with millet farmers or with the immigration of foragers during the early Holocene (∼11.7–8.3 ka).
research objective: In this study, by exploring mitogenomes in Tibetans and surrounding populations (especially those with suggested Neolithic millet farmer ancestry), as well as radiocarbon dating of cereal remains from archaeological sites on the TP and northern China, we aimed to address whether millet farmers contributed to the Tibetan gene pool at the time of barley dispersal to the TP (∼3.6 ka), thus providing deeper insight into the origin of Tibetans.
methods: Blood samples from 671 Tibetans from 11 Tibetan populations were collected, covering all seven districts of Tibet. Blood samples from an additional 11 Chinese individuals belonging to haplogroups of interest were also collected for mitogenome sequencing. Complete mtDNA genomes of the samples were enriched by capture-based strategies using a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit (MyGenostics Inc., Beijing, China). Sequencing was carried out using an Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform at MyGenostics. Quality control was performed according to previous research. The sequencing outputs were edited and aligned by Lasergene (DNAStar Inc., Madison, Wisconsin, USA) and compared with the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence. Phylogenetic trees of lineages of interest were reconstructed manually based on the complete sequences and confirmed by mtphyl software. Bayesian skyline plots (BSP) for effective population size (Nef) through time were reconstructed based on 13 protein coding regions using BEAST v1.7.5. In detail, 20 samples were picked randomly from each of the 11 Tibetan populations and pooled as one data set to perform BSP analysis.
dataset: Blood samples from 671 Tibetans from 11 Tibetan populations were collected, covering all seven districts of Tibet. Blood samples from an additional 11 Chinese individuals belonging to haplogroups of interest were also collected for mitogenome sequencing.
findings: M9a1a1c1b1a and A11a1a were more frequent in Tibetans ∼3.6 ka. Both M9a1a1c1b1a and A11a1a are distributed ubiquitously in contemporary Tibetans, with total frequencies ranging from 12.0% (Baqing County, Naqu) to 37.5% (Ngari) across all regional Tibetan populations studied. This suggests that the millet farmer lineages contributed to and existed in the proto-gene pool of Tibetans before their expansion to different regions on the TP. Indeed, much closer genetic affinity was observed among all regional Tibetan populations, with haplogroup M9a1a1c1b1a contributing most to this clustering pattern, implying that millet farmer components played an important role in shaping the genetic landscape of Tibetans.

Concept Completion.Answer: 671 Tibetans across 11 Tibetan populations covering all seven districts of Tibet

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to study genetic adaptation in high-altitude populations?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of DNA microarrays to analyze whole-genome chip data from 150 Tibetan individuals and non-Tibetan East Asians, focusing on approximately 700,000 loci including nuclear genome, mitochondrial DNA, and Y chromosome.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that examines the genetic diversity of Tibetan populations in relation to their adaptation to high-altitude environments?
Example.Answer: A dataset that examines this is the collection of blood samples from 671 Tibetans across 11 populations, which were used for mitogenome sequencing to study the genetic diversity and adaptation of Tibetan populations to high-altitude environments.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a research approach used to investigate the historical genetic contributions to modern Tibetan populations?
Example.Answer: An example of a research approach is the use of mitogenome sequencing of blood samples from Tibetans and surrounding populations, combined with radiocarbon dating of cereal remains, to explore the genetic contributions of Neolithic millet farmers to the Tibetan gene pool around 3.6 kilo-years ago.

Feature Specification.Answer: stable genetic differences, molecular evolutionary characteristics, response to low oxygen levels

Definition.Question: What does 'phylogenetic tree reconstruction' entail in the context of genetic lineage studies?
Definition.Answer: Phylogenetic tree reconstruction involves creating a visual representation of the evolutionary relationships among various genetic lineages based on genetic data. In the context of genetic lineage studies, particularly with Tibetan populations, phylogenetic trees are manually constructed using complete sequences to understand the historical genetic connections and lineage evolution, often confirmed by specific software like mtphyl.

Definition.Question: What are Bayesian skyline plots and how do they contribute to understanding population size changes over time?
Definition.Answer: Bayesian skyline plots are statistical methods used to infer past population dynamics, such as changes in population size over time, based on genetic data. They are constructed using Bayesian inference and can provide insights into historical population sizes, as seen in studies of Tibetan populations where they help reconstruct effective population size through time using genome data from multiple samples.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of DNA microarray analysis in high-altitude Tibetan populations compare to the capture-based strategy for mitogenome sequencing in terms of data resolution and genetic insights?
Comparison.Answer: DNA microarray analysis in high-altitude Tibetan populations provides data on approximately 700,000 SNPs across nuclear, mitochondrial, and Y-chromosomal DNA, offering insights into genetic adaptations to high-altitude environments. In contrast, capture-based mitogenome sequencing focuses on the entire mitochondrial genome, allowing for detailed phylogenetic analysis and insights into historical population movements and genetic affiliations, particularly in relation to Neolithic millet farmer ancestry.

Interpretation.Question: How can data collection techniques be optimized to accurately capture genetic adaptations to high-altitude environments in different Tibetan populations?
Interpretation.Answer: Blood samples from Tibetans across various populations were collected, focusing on mitogenome sequencing to identify genetic adaptations. This approach allows for the study of specific haplogroups and their distribution, contributing to understanding genetic adaptations to high-altitude environments.

Interpretation.Question: What inferences can be made about the evolutionary history of Tibetan populations based on their genomic data, and how might this impact future research directions?
Interpretation.Answer: The genomic data suggest that Tibetan populations have a closer genetic affinity with certain haplogroups, indicating a shared evolutionary history influenced by Neolithic migrations. This understanding can guide future research in exploring the extent of these genetic influences and their impact on current adaptations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to use specific data collection methods when studying genetic adaptations to high-altitude environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Using specific data collection methods, such as DNA microarrays or mitogenome sequencing, is crucial when studying genetic adaptations to high-altitude environments because these methods allow for detailed analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms and other genetic markers that have undergone positive selection in response to hypoxic conditions. This precision helps to elucidate the molecular evolution and adaptation mechanisms in these unique populations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the genetic differences observed between Tibetan populations and neighboring groups at different altitudes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The genetic differences observed between Tibetan populations and neighboring groups at different altitudes can be attributed to the long-term adaptation to the extreme hypoxic environment of the Tibetan Plateau. This adaptation has led to positive selection on high-altitude related genes and stable genetic differences in single nucleotide polymorphisms, influenced by ancient migrations and the introduction of agriculture, which shaped the genetic landscape over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the impact of collecting blood samples from multiple Tibetan populations on the understanding of genetic contributions from Neolithic millet farmers?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Collecting blood samples from multiple Tibetan populations allows for a comprehensive analysis of genetic diversity and helps to identify haplogroups that are more frequent in Tibetans, suggesting potential contributions from Neolithic millet farmers to the Tibetan gene pool and providing insights into the historical genetic landscape and migration patterns.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of archaeological evidence and genetic data collection influence the understanding of human settlement patterns on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating archaeological evidence with genetic data collection could provide a more complete picture of human settlement patterns on the Tibetan Plateau by correlating genetic findings with historical timelines of cereal cultivation and domestication, thus enhancing our understanding of the timing and nature of human occupations and migrations.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to study the mitogenomes of Tibetans and surrounding populations in the context of genetic research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Studying the mitogenomes of Tibetans and surrounding populations provides deeper insights into the origins and genetic makeup of Tibetans, particularly in relation to Neolithic migrations. This research aims to determine whether the millet farmers contributed to the Tibetan gene pool during the dispersal of barley agriculture to the Tibetan Plateau, thereby addressing gaps in previous genetic and archaeological studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in using DNA microarray technology for differentiating genetic variations between high-altitude Tibetan populations and other East Asian groups?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using DNA microarray (DNA Array) technology to genotype approximately 700,000 loci from each sample, covering nuclear genome, mitochondrial DNA, and Y chromosome. This allows for the analysis of SNP differences, genes, and signaling pathways between high-altitude Tibetan populations and other East Asian groups.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are blood samples processed and prepared for high-throughput sequencing to study mitochondrial genome variations in Tibetan populations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Blood samples are collected and the complete mtDNA genomes are enriched using capture-based strategies with a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit. Sequencing is performed on an Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform, and quality control is conducted. The sequencing results are edited, aligned, and compared with a reference sequence, followed by phylogenetic analysis.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable researchers to accurately differentiate between high-altitude adaptation genes and general genetic variations in Tibetan populations?
Enablement.Answer: DNA microarray methods are used to compare whole-genome chip data from Tibetan and non-Tibetan East Asian individuals, which helps in identifying differential SNPs, genes, and pathways associated with high-altitude adaptation in Tibetans.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of radiocarbon dating with genetic analysis enable a better understanding of the historical gene flow and agricultural practices in the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: By combining mitogenome exploration with radiocarbon dating of cereal remains, researchers aim to determine the contribution of Neolithic millet farmers to the Tibetan gene pool during the barley dispersal period, providing insights into the origins of Tibetans.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of capture-based strategies for mtDNA enrichment facilitate detailed phylogenetic analysis of Tibetan populations?
Enablement.Answer: Capture-based strategies using a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit allow for the enrichment of complete mtDNA genomes, which are then sequenced and analyzed to reconstruct phylogenetic trees and assess population size changes over time, aiding in the understanding of genetic affinities and historical migrations.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be variations in the frequency of certain haplogroups among different Tibetan populations in genetic datasets?
Expectation.Answer: M9a1a1c1b1a and A11a1a haplogroups are distributed ubiquitously in contemporary Tibetans, with frequency variations ranging from 12.0% to 37.5% across different regions, suggesting that historical migrations and the genetic contributions from millet farmers have shaped these regional genetic differences.

Expectation.Question: Why might nuclear genome data be essential for understanding high-altitude adaptation in Tibetan populations?
Expectation.Answer: Nuclear genome data provide a comprehensive view of genetic adaptations, as they involve approximately 700,000 loci, including nuclear, mitochondrial, and Y chromosome genes. This allows for the analysis of SNP differences, genes, and pathways involved in high-altitude adaptation, offering insights into the molecular evolution under selective pressures such as hypoxia.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what additional data collection methods could complement blood sample sequencing to provide a more comprehensive understanding of genetic adaptations in high-altitude populations?
Judgmental.Answer: Complementary data collection methods could include anthropometric measurements, physiological studies on oxygen utilization, and longitudinal studies to observe changes over time. Incorporating environmental data, such as climate and altitude variation, and using advanced sequencing technologies like whole-genome sequencing could also provide a more comprehensive understanding of genetic adaptations in high-altitude populations.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how data collection methods in genomic studies account for genetic diversity among different Tibetan populations.
Assertion.Answer: Blood samples from 671 Tibetans from 11 Tibetan populations were collected, covering all seven districts of Tibet. This approach ensures a comprehensive representation of genetic diversity among different Tibetan populations.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on the techniques used to capture and sequence mitochondrial DNA in population genetics research.
Assertion.Answer: Complete mtDNA genomes of the samples were enriched by capture-based strategies using a MyGenostics Human Mitochondria Capture Kit. Sequencing was carried out using an Illumina HiSeq X Ten platform, with quality control performed according to previous research.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding genetic datasets related to high-altitude adaptation in Tibetan populations and discuss the implications for evolutionary research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding genetic datasets could involve increasing the sample size and diversity, including more regional populations and individuals with varying degrees of high-altitude habitation. Integrating additional genomic technologies such as whole-genome sequencing or epigenetic profiling might provide deeper insights. This expansion could lead to a more comprehensive understanding of the genetic basis for high-altitude adaptation, contributing to broader evolutionary research by elucidating how environmental pressures shape genetic diversity and adaptation.
